abstract.text: Add a range of visual effects to a RealityKit view by attaching a
particle emitter component to an entity.

metadata.title: Simulating particles in your visionOS app

inlineContent.text: Define and tailor a particle system by creating and configuring a
particle emitter component and then adding it to an entity.
A particle emitter component can simulate various effects including fire, smoke,
confetti, and so on.
The sample app presents sliders, toggles, buttons, and color pickers
that adjust the particle emitter’s settings.
You change the appearance and behavior of the particles it emits with these
controls, including their size, shape, and speed.
The app’s controls let you quickly try a variety of particle effects
that illustrate the range of possibilities for your app.
You can add a particle emitter to your RealityKit scene in four steps.
Create an entity.
Create a particle emitter component.
Add that component to the entity.
Add the entity to a scene.
You can turn any entity into a particle emitter, including one that’s already
in your app’s scene.
The app creates a new entity with the default initializer
Create a
instance by calling one of its
initializers.
You can also create a particle emitter from a preset by accessing one
of the properties of the
type.
Each preset is an initial configuration that sets up a new particle emitter
system.
You can use a preset as a starting point and then alter the behavior and
appearance of the emitter and its particles by modifying the component’s
properties.
This approach may be more convenient than configuring every property of a
particle emitter component.

inlineContent.text: The scene can now present the entity as a particle emitter because it has the
component that defines the look and behavior of the emitter and the particles it
creates.

content.text: Configure the behavior of the emitter’s particles

inlineContent.text: You can alter the behavior of a particle system by changing the values of a
instance’s properties.
For example, the
property adjusts the
starting speed of the particles as the emitter creates them, and the
property modifies
how many times per second the emitter creates a new particle.
This example modifies the component’s
and
properties to
and
, respectively, from their default values
and
which creates more particles that move slower.
If you adjust one or more particle component properties,
you need to replace the entity’s current particle component instance
by setting it again because component instances are from value types.

content.text: Configure the color for the emitter’s particles

inlineContent.text: You can customize the color of the particles an emitter component creates by
setting the
property to one of the enumeration cases, including:
A particle with a constant color maintains the same color throughout its
lifetime, but a particle with an evolving color gradually changes from one color
to another over the duration of its lifetime.
The app has two methods that configure particles with a constant color.
The
method creates a
instance
by passing the color a person selects in the app’s UI to the
enumeration case, and then creates a constant color from that value.

code: // Create a single color value instance.
// Create a constant color from the single color value.
// Change the particle color for the emitter.
// Replace the entity's emitter component with the current configuration.

inlineContent.text: The app’s
method also creates a constant color that’s
random by passing two colors from the app’s UI to the
enumeration case.

code: // Create a random color value instance between two colors.
let randomColor = ParticleColorValue.random(a: color1, b: color2)
// Create a constant color from the random color value.
// Change the particle color for the emitter.
// Replace the entity's emitter component with the current configuration.

inlineContent.text: The enumeration case creates a color value from the two input colors
by selecting a random interpolation value between them.
The app’s
method configures an emitter’s particles so
that they shift from one color to another over time by creating an evolving
color.

code: // Create two single color value instances.
// Create an evolving color that shifts from one color value to another.
// Change the particle color for the emitter.
// Replace the entity's emitter component with the current configuration.

inlineContent.text: The method creates an evolving color by passing two single color value instances
to the
enumeration case.

content.text: Customize the appearance of the emitter’s particles with images

inlineContent.text: The app lets a person change the appearance of the emitter’s particles by
applying an image to each.
It does this by creating a
instance from an image and
assigning it to the emitter’s
property.
You can create a texture resource by loading an image from the app’s bundle with
the
method, or by passing a
instance to
the
factory method.
The app generates a texture resource in its
method by taking these steps:
Retrieve a symbol from SF Symbols using the symbol’s name.
Draw the image as a template onto a white background in a graphics context.
Retrieve the image from the context.
Pass the final image to the texture resource type’s factory method.

code: // Create a UIImage from a symbol name.
guard var symbolImage = UIImage(systemName: name) else {
// Create a new version that always uses the template rendering mode.
// Set the color's texture to white so that the app can apply a color
// Draw the image with the context.
let rectangle = CGRect(origin: CGPoint.zero, size: imageSize)
// Retrieve the image from the context.
// Retrieve the Core Graphics version of the image.
// Generate the texture resource from the Core Graphics image.

inlineContent.text: The method makes a texture resource that works with the emitter’s current color
by starting with all white before drawing the image onto it.
The app presents a slider that changes the
property.
In the example below, the slider’s value is
radians,
which is equivalent to 30º.

abstract.text: Simulate and render 3D content for use in your augmented reality apps.
Adds a new component to the set, or overrides an existing one.
All the components that an entity stores.
Creates a new entity.
A component that emits particles.
Options for specifying whether the particle color is a single color, or if the particle should take a random color in the given range.
The system will choose a random color for each particle between the given two Colors.
The particle will be the given Color.
The particle will remain the given color throughout its lifetime.
The particle’s color will start at the
color and transition over its lifetime to the
color.
Defines a plus/minus range (in radians) from which a value is randomly selected to offset
The number of particles emitted over the emission duration. Defaults to 100.
The color of particles.
The image that each particle will use (requires pre-multiplied RGB values). Defaults to a white circular texture.
Initial configurations that can be set when starting a new simulation.
The initial speed, in meters per second, for newly spawned particles. Defaults to 0.5.
A view that contains RealityKit content.
The content of a visionOS reality view.
Adds an entity to this content.
A representation of a texture.
Synchronously creates a texture resource from an in-memory Core Graphics image.
Returns a texture resource by synchronously loading it from a bundle.
Simulate physical interactions between entities or systems.
A bitmap image or image mask.

particles-alert.alt: A screen recording of the app's particle emitter producing particles that have the shape of a yellow triangle with an exclamation mark in the center. Each particle has a random rotation between 30 degrees clockwise and 30 degrees counterclockwise because a person set the angle-variation slider in the app's UI to 30 degrees.

particles-base.alt: A large visionOS window with a blurred glass background, displaying pink particles flowing from the bottom to the top.

particles-color-evolve.alt: A screen recording of the app's particle emitter producing particles that transition from one color to another as they flow upward from the bottom of the app's window in visionOS.

particles-color-one.alt: A screen recording of the app's particle emitter producing red particles, which flow upward from the bottom of the app's window in visionOS.

particles-color-random.alt: A screen recording of the app's particle emitter producing particles, each of which is a random shade of purple because a person selected red and blue colors in the app's UI. The particles flow upward from the bottom of the app's window in visionOS.

particles-dense.alt: A screen capture of a particle emitter that's producing pink particles that flow from the bottom of a visionOS window to its center.

particles-main.alt: A large visionOS window with a blurred glass background, displaying particles flowing from the bottom to the center. The particles are transitioning between pink and purple.

particles-presets-fireworks.alt: A screen capture of a particle emitter with particles in the form of fireworks that project upward from the bottom of a visionOS window, and then explode near the top.

particles-presets-impact.alt: A screen capture of a particle emitter with particles that emit in a radial pattern and simulate dust from an object hitting the ground.

particles-presets-magic.alt: A screen capture of a particle emitter with particles that twinkle and emit spawn particles.

particles-presets-rain.alt: A screen capture of a particle emitter with particles that move downwards fast, and are semi-opaque, rendered as streaks.

particles-presets-snow.alt: A screen capture of a particle emitter with particles that softly fall, and incorporate motion from a noise pattern.

particles-presets-sparks.alt: A screen capture of a particle emitter with particles projecting from the bottom left side. The particles are quick and short lived particles that accumulate color to simulate welding sparks.
